NASHVILLE

Residential - sales

Home sales are down in Nashville, despite it being the spring selling season.

In April in the greater Nashville region, there were 2,963 closings – down 3 percent from the year before, according to Greater Nashville Realtors.

Pending home sales also fell, by 8 percent, to 2,743.

The median sales price in April was $500,000 for a home, up from $490,000 the month before but down a hair from $505,000 in April 2024.

The typical home is spending 50 days on the market – slightly longer than April 2024, when it took 46 days for homes to sell.

Residential - rentals

Rents were down in Nashville in April, coming in at $2,100 a month for the average apartment – down $193 from the year before, according to listings and data platform Zillow.

However, the average rent was higher than the prior month’s, by $100.

Overall, rents in Nashville are still among the priciest in the country, as rents in the city are about 14 percent higher than the national average.

Development

Among the biggest redevelopment projects in Nashville underway is the rebranding of the city’s river district.

Rebranded the River District on the East Bank, the area spans 750 acres along the Cumberland River in northwest Nashville, where nearly 25 developments are already in the pipeline, the Nashville Business Journal reported.

The River District is being pushed by CET Holdings, E3 Construction Services and Red Seal Homes, each of which has active projects in the area. CET Holdings is behind the Horizon mixed-use development and Bentley Ridge townhome communities, while Red Seal is advancing its Proximity and SkyVue residential projects. E3 Construction holds the largest land portfolio and is planning four residential projects within the district.

The rebranding comes as Texas-based Ewing Properties’ recent $200 million listing for The Riverside, a 65-acre waterside site slated for a massive $2.5 billion development. Three public parks and 5 million square feet of residential, office and retail space are in the plans. Rob Lowe of Stream Realty is marketing the property.

The River District lies a few miles from major developments along West Trinity Lane, including the under-construction Titans stadium and Oracle’s planned tech hub and headquarters on the East Bank, set to connect to New City Properties’ mixed-use redevelopment of the Neuhoff meat-packing plant.

Also in the East Bank, Carl Icahn’s firm is selling a 45-acre former scrapyard for $225 million. A local investment group led by veteran investors J. David Byerley and Sam Lingo are acquiring the property at a price well above its previous $25 million book value. The investment group initially targeted $350 million in fundraising for the acquisition.

Commercial - office leasing

The asking rent for office space in the Music City soared more than 8 percent year over year, coming in at $36.40 during the first quarter, according to a report from real estate firm Savills.

The rent for prime, Class-A space also rose, by almost 8 percent, to $39.41 as there was strong demand for top-in-class office space, particularly among technology, advertising, media and information companies in the Downtown submarket.

However, despite the rent increases, leasing activity dropped in the first quarter from the year before by about 33 percent to 0.4 million square feet. The availability rate also inched up 340 basis points to 23.8 percent, in part because of more sublease options hitting the market.

The largest lease inked during the first quarter was 65,548 square feet at 500 11th Avenue, Oracle’s new location. Oracle also expanded its space at 601 11th Avenue, taking 31,578 square feet.

Commercial investment sales

Nashville’s pandemic-era office boom is in the rear view.

The city’s biggest office towers have collectively lost nearly $400 million in appraised value, a painful correction from the pricing peak of the pandemic boom, reshaping how owners, buyers and city officials value the downtown commercial core.

Davidson County’s reappraisal dropped values for 14 of the city’s largest non-government office towers — excluding those built in the past four years — by an average of 18.7 percent, with some icons faring far worse, the Nashville Business Journal reported.

To name a few: Bridgestone Tower, a 30-story skyline anchor ranked as the 10th-largest office building downtown, saw its value plunge nearly 33 percent from $213 million in 2021 to $142.7 million. Symphony Place, which is undergoing renovations after recent tenant losses, fell by $43 million, or 23 percent. Fifth Third Center and Amazon Tower I also saw declines in the tens of millions.

The reassessment comes as downtown Nashville office vacancy hit 24.4 percent, above the national average of 20.8 percent the first quarter, according to Cushman & Wakefield, as distress sales ripple across the market. The $17 million sale of Philips Plaza, an 85 percent loss from its last trade at $39 per square foot, set the tone in December, followed by steep losses on Parkway Towers and Court Square.

Additionally, property owners could be in for a jolt as the next wave of tax assessments approaches.

The Tennessee Comptroller’s Office reported the total property value in Davidson County has soared to more than $220 billion, up 72 percent since 2020, the Nashville Business Journal reported.

Property assessments, used to determine tax obligations, have increased nearly 50 percent in that same period, according to the state’s 2024 Tax Aggregate Report, released Monday.

The figures don’t reflect the official reappraisal that Metro Nashville is conducting this year, but they offer a preview of the elevated values expected when assessment notices go out in May.

The reappraisal covers all 289,784 parcels in Davidson County and could trigger widespread property tax increases for residential and commercial owners.

The last countywide appraisal, in 2021, brought a 34.1 percent median property value jump, even amid pandemic disruptions. This time, the adjustments may be more severe, particularly for property types that received breaks during Covid, such as hotels and retail.

They are likely to see significant increases, as the assessor is expected to factor in their post-pandemic recovery and growth since 2021, said Caren Nichol, a property tax attorney at Evans Petree.

Basic Stats:

Population: 2 million in the metro area (Nashville-Davidson-Murfreesboro-Franklin)Politics: Nashville has a strong mayor, with a Dem mayor, Freddie O’Connell, and a 40-member Metropolitan Council (the third-largest city council in the country, after New York and Chicago!). There’s also a popularly elected vice mayor who presides over the council, but only votes to break ties. Council members are only part-time legislators, paid about $23K annually. History: Nashville was established as a fort in the late 18th century, and became important because it’s along the Cumberland River, which is a tributary to the Ohio. Its population grew dramatically though the 19th century, and it became the Tennessee state capital in 1843. It was an early center for the iron business, with ore deposits across the region, and an important railroad center. The city was a lot of suburbanization after WWII, and to maintain its tax base it annexed 42 square miles of suburbs in the early 1960’s. It also saw a big boom in the 1990s thanks to a pro-urban renewal mayor who built and renovated a large number of city landmarks. Today it has one of the fastest growing economies in the nation, with a big influx of white collar jobs. Healthcare is the largest industry, but there’s been growth in the auto industry, plus large offices for several top accounting and consulting firms like EY and Deloitte. Wealth manager Alliance Berstein announced that they would move their HQ there by 2024, and Oracle is building a $1.2B campus there. And of course, it’s one of the largest music centers in the world, and has a huge number of universities, including Vanderbilt. Priciest neighborhoods: Nashville’s priciest home ever listed this summer, but it’s further afield than most listings. Nearer to Nashville’s center, there are pricey listings in neighborhoods like Music Row and The Gulch. A bit further out, but still within city limits, homes regularly sell over $5 million in Belle Meade and Forest Hills.

Last Updated: May 14, 2025

PHOENIX

Residential - sales

In the Phoenix metropolitan area as of February, the median home sale price was up 3.5 percent year over year, coming in at $470,000, according to listings and data platform Redfin. However, the median price per square foot inched down to $279, or by 3.1 percent, from the year before.

Homes are lasting longer on the market in Phoenix. Sellers are parting with their homes after an average of 59 days, compared to 50 days in February 2024. However, there are more deals getting done: 1,336 homes were sold in February, about 100 more than this time last year.

The percentage of homes selling above their listing prices inched up 0.8 percent to 17.5 percent, but 33.4 percent of homes – 3.9 percent more than last year – are trading at discounts.

Residential - rentals

The average rent in Phoenix in the first quarter of 2025 fell 2.3 percent from the year before to $1,560, according to a market report from real estate firm MMG, which noted that rents are falling largely because of competition and using concessions to attract buyers.

The occupancy rate also is lower, down 20 basis points to 91.9 percent.

Absorption came in at 5,149 in the first quarter – reflecting record-high demand – and there were 4,850 units delivered. Deliveries are down 36 percent compared to the end of 2024, indicating a slowdown in construction in the area.

Development

A state law that would bypass local laws to allow the development of duplexes, triplexes, fourplexes and rental townhomes in neighborhoods zoned for single-family homes is sparking organized opposition months before it’s set to take effect.

The opposition in Arizona, where the law applies to areas within 1 mile of designated central business districts, is centered in Phoenix, the Arizona Republic reported.

Pushback is similar to various efforts by homeowners in California to frustrate recently passed state laws intended to spur development of duplexes in single-family neighborhoods.

Arizona’s House Bill 2721, which was passed in 2024 and goes into effect on Jan. 1, 2026, would cover an area of the City of Phoenix that includes more than 10 neighborhoods considered historic.

A number of them, including the Willo, Coronado and Encanto-Palmcroft districts, are chock full of homes valued at more than $1 million, more than double the median price in the city.

House Bill 2721 applies to municipalities with populations of 75,000 or more, and limits new developments to two stories. The roster of cities where the law will apply also includes Tempe, Mesa, Glendale, Tucson and Flagstaff.

Furthermore, as greater Phoenix grows, boutique home builders are targeting small parcels of land for high-density infill developments.

The compact infill developments offer homebuyers a central location closer to work than the sprawling developments preferred by larger developers, while allowing builders to maximize space efficiency, the Phoenix Business Journal reported.

Despite the challenges of finding and rezoning suitable land, developers see strong returns.

According to Mishkin, metro Phoenix has around 10 to 15 such projects at any time, featuring densities of eight to 15 units per acre. The appeal lies in proximity to employment hubs, contrasting with large-scale developments on the city’s outskirts.

Commercial - office leasing

The Phoenix office market recorded more than 441,000 square feet of positive absorption in the first quarter of the year, according to a report from real estate services firm CBRE.

Asking rents for office space ticked up $0.19 from the quarter before, as the vacancy rate inched down 90 basis points from the quarter before, coming in at 22.1 percent. However, the asking rent fell 4.7 percent year over year to $30 per square foot.

The first quarter did not see any new deliveries or construction starts, but the city is expected to see two large deliveries in the second quarter.

Additionally, the suburban coworking inventory in the Phoenix market has surged in the last two years, according to a recent Yardi Matrix report.

Between 2023 and early 2025, the Valley’s suburban coworking footprint leapt from 1.5 million to 4.5 million square feet — a 185 percent increase — propelling Phoenix to sixth place nationally for suburban coworking square footage, according to the Phoenix Business Journal. Urban coworking also grew, albeit more modestly, rising from about 900,000 square feet in 2023 to 1 million in 2025.

The shift has reshaped the local market: suburban locations accounted for roughly 60 percent of Phoenix’s coworking inventory in 2023, and now represent 82 percent.

SEATTLE

Residential - sales

During the first quarter in the Emerald City, the median home sale price climbed 6 percent, according to a report from Brooke Davis Real Estate. The median price is now $960,000.

That is the same amount of growth that Seattle saw during the first quarter of 2024.

There are 14 percent more new listings – 2,293 listings – on the market compared to the year before

Competition in the city remains fierce, as 71 percent of homes traded at or above their list prices. That’s up from 69 percent the year prior. Additionally, 62 percent of homes are pending within 10 days.

As for Seattle’s submarkets, the median price growth was greatest year over year in the Queen Anne/Magnolia area, where the price rose 12 percent. The steepest median price decline was in West Bellevue, where the median price plunged 18 percent.

Residential - rentals

The average rent in May for Seattle was $1,802 – up $6 from the month before, but down $198 from the year before, according to Zillow.

The average rent in the city is about 3 percent lower than the national average of $1,850.

The Emerald City also has among the smallest new apartments in the nation, with typical units built in the past 10 years at 649 square feet, the Seattle Times reported, citing a report from RentCafe.

The average Seattle squeezebox is 8 percent tighter than the 706 square feet of a decade ago.

Among the 100 U.S. cities with the largest number of rental units, Seattle ranks last for average apartment size, based on February data hauled in by Yardi Matrix.

The reason: as the cost of housing spiked, developers built smaller apartments, including micro-units as small as 150 square feet.

At the same time, new construction in Seattle focused on studios and one-bedrooms, which have also shrunk since 2015, according to the report. The average studio in Seattle is 371 square feet, down from 442 square feet a decade ago.

Development

The City of Seattle is amending its land use code to better streamline permitting as Sound Transit works toward the West Seattle and Ballard light rail extensions, according to The Urbanist.

One proposed set of changes details development standards meant only for light rail facilities. Otherwise, the stations would be required to stick to neighborhoods’ development regulations.

Another update involves expanding bicycle parking at the new stations. The city’s policy of planting three trees for every one removed is also being revised.

The changes were part of the partnership agreement between the city and Sound Transit formed in 2017.

The city is also working to make it easier for developers to construct new housing, according to The Urbanist.

The council recently greenlit extending permit applications and existing permits for permits submitted under the 2015 and 2018 building code. Otherwise, the projects would have to be redesigned to align with the new code from 2021 – something developers note would be cost prohibitive.

Commercial - office leasing

Seattle’s office vacancy rate inched up to 31.2 percent in the first quarter from 28.1 percent in 2024, according to a report from Colliers, which noted that this is the smallest yearly increase since the fourth quarter of 2022.

Accompanying this vacancy rate growth was a drop in Class A asking rents, which fell 1.8 percent from the same time last year to $55.36 per square foot.

Much of the leasing activity during the quarter stemmed from lease renewals or tenants downsizing their space. Many tenants are moving around top-in-class space as they are working to bring their employees back to the office full time.

Last Updated: May 13, 2025

DENVER

Residential - sales

Home buyers in Denver have tip-toed into the spring selling season with caution, creating the biggest backlog of available properties in more than a decade.

Listings of condominiums and single-family homes in the Mile High City rose 22.5 percent to 11,964 last month, the greatest number since fall 2011 and a year-over-year jump of 71 percent, the Denver Post reported, citing figures from the Denver Metro Association of Realtors.

Denver’s unsold inventory rose five times faster than the rest of the U.S., whose listings ticked up 6.1 from a year earlier, with the total number of available homes up 13.7 percent, according to Redfin.

The number of new listings across the region increased 10.8 percent last month to 7,062, up 18.1 percent from a year earlier. Listings spent a typical 13 days on the market, compared to 39 days across the U.S.

Sellers offloaded 3,883 homes last month, compared to 3,999 a year earlier. Nationally, home sales were up 13.1 percent on the year, according to Redfin.

“A lot of people who would normally be making moves right now are standing still,” Bliss Ong, a Redfin Premier agent in Seattle, said in a statement. “They want to ride out this period of economic uncertainty and wait until they feel more secure to make this huge financial decision.

The typical price of a single detached home that sold in greater Denver last month was $665,000, up from $660,000 in March and $660,500 in April last year.

Condos rose 0.55 percent on the month to $389,900, down 6 percent year over year, mostly to compensate for higher homeowner association fees.

Residential - rentals

Developers have built so many apartments in greater Denver that empty units have hit a 16-year-high, with cascading rents across the city.

Builders have added 20,822 apartments in the past 12 months, driving vacancy in the Mile High City to 7 percent last quarter, from 5.8 percent late last year, the Denver Post reported, citing a report from the Apartment Association of Metro Denver.

At the same time, the average monthly apartment rent in greater Denver fell to $1,819, from $1,842 — and from $1,846 in the first quarter of 2023. Had typical rents risen with inflation, they’d be $1,951 a month.

“This occurred because we had such a strong and large construction pipeline,” Cary Bruteig, a researcher with Apartment Insights and author of the apartment association report, told the Post.

Apartment vacancy is the highest since the Great Recession of nearly two decades ago.

Douglas County has the lowest vacancy rate at 5.8 percent, while Denver has the highest at 7.7 percent.

Development

Denver Mayor Mike Johnston has set up a dedicated permitting office for developers, cutting red tape in a city where he said it “was too difficult to build things.”

The mayor’s order, his first since he was elected two years ago, aims to handle start-to-finish  building permits in six months — from a current nine to 10 months, the Denver Business Journal reported.

The order follows similar directives of mayors in San Francisco and Los Angeles, who issued executive orders from tackling homelessness and drugs to whisking approvals for affordable housing to quickly rebuilding homes torched by wildfires.

With the new office run by Jill Jennings Golich, the city’s new permitting czar, every project will get permits within 180 days, from its concept plan to its site development plan to a city granted permit, Johnston said.

Under the new permitting office, if a project is in the city’s hands for more than 180 days, the developer can appeal within 14 days with the executive directors of all seven offices that work on permitting approvals, Johnston said.

Meanwhile, landlords of large office buildings and hospitals in Denver have pushed back against city and state green building rules, saying they damage their bottom lines and the economy.

Complaints from various business sectors have led the city Office of Climate Action, Sustainability and Resiliency to redo its Energize Denver, or plan to cut building pollution, the Denver Post reported.

Commercial - office leasing

Denver’s office market didn’t get off to the best start in 2025.

The total vacancy rate ticked up to 26.8 percent – a 70 basis-point increase from the fourth quarter of 2024 – due to the rise in direct vacancy rate compared to sublease vacancy, which fell 10 basis points, according to a report from CBRE. Compared to the year prior, the total vacancy rate for Denver is up by 170 basis points.

Leasing activity also plunged 16 percent from the quarter before to 1.2 million square feet. However, that figure is 6.6 percent higher than the year before, thanks to government and non-profit tenants inking deals.

Asking rents for office space were relatively stable for the third quarter in a row, according to the report. It inched down by 0.4 percent from the end of 2024 to the first quarter, coming in at $33.81 per square foot. This is 1.7 percent higher than the year before.

The fourth quarter of last year saw an increase of office sales, with 19 deals valued at $277.4 million. But that momentum did not continue into the first quarter, when there were three sales totaling $153.3 million.

Basic Stats:

Population: 2.96 million in the metro area (Denver-Aurora-Lakewood)Politics: Denver has a strong mayor-council system, with a Democrat mayor, Mike Johnston, and a 13-member city council, which has 11 districts and two at-large seats. History: Modern Denver came to be in the 1858 Rocky Mountain gold rush, as settlers took over areas that had been set aside as Cheyanne and Arapaho treaty lands. It was a frontier town and a trading and transit hub. A railroad terminus greatly increased the city’s size and prosperity in the late 19th century; it remains the largest city within 500 miles, so it’s an important center for the western plains region and the Front Range. Energy and mining are still important parts of the economy here (in fact, the area was a hub for nuclear energy in the 1960’s, and a waste storage facility contaminated parts of Denver, particularly in the northwestern corner, which remains a problem today), along with government and defense, among other things. Apartment corporation AIMCO is based here, as are a number of fast-casual restaurant groups. Priciest neighborhoods: In Denver, neighborhoods like Cherry Creek, Belcaro, Country Club and Cherry Hills are going to have your priciest listings. There’s a Four Seasons in Downtown Denver now too. But perhaps the most interesting homes will be a (short) flight away, in ritzy ski towns like Aspen, Breckenridge, Vail, and Telluride.

Last Updated: May 9, 2025

LAS VEGAS

Residential - sales

Sales of new homes around Las Vegas have slid into a ditch as would-be buyers struggle with record-high prices.

Developers sold 942 new homes in March across Southern Nevada, 10 percent fewer than a year earlier as the typical price jumped 9.6 percent to a record $530,000, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing figures from locally based Home Builders Research.

At the same time, home builders had 810 net sales, or newly signed sales contracts minus cancellations, which plunged 39 percent. New home permits fell 25 percent from a year ago.

The slowdown points to a shrinking pool of buyers who can or want to pay for the higher-priced, newly built homes in or around Las Vegas.

While new home sales slowed in the wake of record prices, sales of previously owned homes in Southern Nevada rose, despite a price uptick. At the same time, available inventory soared.

Buyers inked contracts for 2,140 used single-family homes in March, up 3 percent from a year earlier, according to Las Vegas Realtors.  They paid a median price of $485,000, up 4 percent.

By the end of the month, more than 5,400 homes were on the market, up 63 percent from the same time last year.

Residential - rentals

In the first quarter of the year in Sin City, the average rental rate was $1.58 per square foot, about the same from last year, according to Colliers. However, the commercial real estate firm expects this figure to drop over the year.

More units were on the market than the same time a year ago as well – 1,162. As a result, the monthly asking rent for an apartment fell from $1,473 the year before to $1,461.

However, there are fewer apartments under construction in Las Vegas. As of the first quarter, 4,774 were being built, down from 6,625 a year ago and 5,800 the quarter before.

Residential - luxury

Well-heeled buyers would just as soon settle for a palatial pad in Las Vegas near jingling casinos than a Los Angeles estate near the beach.

Sin City, with its summer mercury topping 120 degrees, is a hotter home market than L.A., the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing a study from Zonda, a new residential construction data firm.

The desert city has become the eighth-most demanding market for luxury home buyers, edging out Boston and nearby Southern California, from Beverly Hills to Malibu.

“The lack of state income taxes and reasonable property tax rates combined with world-class entertainment, sports and dining are a major draw for affluent households,” Sean Fergus, executive director of economic research with Zonda, told the Review-Journal.

The high-income job market in Las Vegas has grown 7.9 percent since 2019, per Zonda.

Development

Developers in landlocked Las Vegas have reaped a bonanza with auction buys of dozens of acres of land from the federal government for a combined $16.5 million.

The Bureau of Land Management listed 10 parcels of land on Energy.net, of which eight — comprising 41.85 acres — sold, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported, citing the BLM.

Combined the purchases work out to $394,265 per acre.

The developers paid more than $1.2 million over fair market value for parcels between 2.5 acres and 25 acres. Two of the largest lots, at 25 acres and 10 acres, didn’t sell.

Funds from the BLM land auction will pay for recreational opportunities and wildland fire reduction, according to the agency. The BLM manages more than 245 million acres of public land, primarily in 12 western states.

Developers in Las Vegas point to a local land crunch, with one builder saying 25,000 acres of land around Las Vegas Valley are available for development, with the region poised to run out of buildable land in as little as seven years, according to the Review-Journal.

Home builders at a Keller Williams’ Meet the Builders panel in March cited challenges to development, including the lack of land, high land costs, record residential real estate prices and high mortgage rates.

Commercial - office leasing

The vacancy rate for Las Vegas’s office sector held somewhat steady in the first quarter compared to the year before, at 12.2 percent, according to CBRE. The vacancy rate in the fourth quarter of 2024 was 12.8 percent.

Vacancy was the lowest in the Southwest submarket, where it came in at 6.7 percent in the first quarter. The Central East submarket recorded the highest vacancy rate of 27.4 percent.

In general, leasing activity has been similar to past years, according to the commercial real estate firm. The average asking rents in the prime Southwest and West markets were relatively stable at $3.01 per square foot and $3.10 per square foot, respectively. The asking rent in the struggling Central East sector also held constant at $2.41 per square foot but below the average for the city for the quarter, $2.63 per square foot.

Las Vegas in the first quarter did not see any new buildings be delivered or break ground – similar to the lack of activity in 2024.

The largest deal inked in the first quarter was TC Group’s sublease of 19,996 square feet of space at 400 Stuart Avenue in Downtown. In the SOuthwest, Deloitte signed on for a 11,929-square-foot expansion at 8474 Rozita Lee Avenue.

Basic Stats:

Population: 2.3 million in the metro area (Las Vegas-Henderson-Paradise)Politics: Vegas has a council-manager model, with six council members, the mayor presiding, and a council-appointed City Manager executing decisions. The current mayor, Carolyn Goodman, is an independent, and the council is four-two Dem-Rep. It’s worth noting that a big chunk of the people who live around Vegas live in unincorporated areas, most of which are governed by Clark County. History: Las Vegas was a total backwater until the 1930s, despite activity in the area from both early pioneers and Mormon settlers. It was officially founded in 1905 as a stopping point for the Union Pacific railroad but didn’t take off until 1931 when, in the same year, construction started on the Hoover Dam and Nevada legalized gambling and instituted more flexible divorce laws. The first casino popped up that year, though the first ones on the Strip wouldn’t materialize until the early 1940’s. The town started to gain notoriety for its nightlife after World War II and attracted attention and investment from organized crime figures like Bugsy Siegel. The population boomed through the 1950’s and ‘60s. The ‘60s and ‘70s saw the opening of some of the most famous resorts, like Caesar’s and the original MGM. The ‘80s saw the first mega-resort, the Mirage, which marked the transition into a wider range of entertainment in Vegas, including live music, shows, art, and food in addition to gaming. When the Bellagio opened in the 1990s it was the most expensive hotel in the world, having cost $1.7 billion. Tourism, gaming, and conventions are the town’s main economic drivers. Priciest neighborhoods: Even the highest rollers don’t live on the Strip. Vegas’ wealthiest residents head for gated communities in nearby Summerlin, like The Ridges and Summit Club, or in areas of Henderson like MacDonald Highlands and Southern Highlands.
